questions.text: Disobedience to quarantine rule is punishable under which section/s of IPC?
questions.solution:
• 269 IPC - Negligent act likely to spread infection of disease danger­ous to life.
  • 270 IPC - Malignant act likely to spread infection of disease danger­ous to life.
  • 271 IPC - Disobedience to quarantine rule.

questions.text: Toxalbumin is not present in
questions.solution:
• A toxalbumin or phytotoxin is a toxic protein, which resembles a bacterial toxin in its action and antigenic in nature. It causes agglutination of red cells with haemo­lysis.
  • Toxalbumin is present in 1. Ricinus communis (RICIN), Croton tiglium (CROTIN), and Abrus precatorius (ABRIN).

questions.text: Correctly match the following:
questions.solution:
1. Declaration of Geneva = Hippocratic oath
  2. Declaration of Oslo = Therapeutic abortion
  3. Declaration of Tokyo = Torture
  4. Declaration of Helsinki = Human experimentation
  5. Declaration of Istanbul= Organ trafficking
  6. Declaration of Sydney = Brain death
  7. Declaration of Malta = Hunger strike
  8. Venice = Terminal illness
  9. Madrid = Professional autonomy

questions.text: Paradoxical undressing is seen in:
questions.solution: • Paradoxical undressing is a term for a phenomenon frequently seen in cases of lethal hypothermia. Shortly before death, the person will remove all their clothes, as if they were burning up, when in fact they are freezing. Because of this, people who have frozen to death are often found naked and are misidentified as victims of a violent crime. The reason for this paradoxical behavior seems to be the effect of a cold-induced paralysis of the nerves in the vessel walls, which leads to a vasodilatation, giving a feeling of warmth.

choices.text: Singeing of eyebrows and facial hair
Blackish soot deposit on posterior part of tongue

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presented to the emergency with extensive burns. The patient had grade 3 burns on the face, back upper arms and forearms along with singeing of hairs. Which of these is not a proof of inhalation burns?
questions.solution: • By definition, inhalation injury is injury to the oropharynx, nasopharynx, trachea, bronchi, or lungs from exposure to smoke or heated gas. Soot deposit is due to the inhalation. Oxides of nitrogen liberated during burns may convert sputum into yellow. Mucosal injury may cause hoarseness and stridor. Singeing will not happen by inhalation.

questions.text: Best stain to identify Barr body is
questions.solution: • Feulgen reaction by using acriflavine is the best staining technique for demonstration of Barr bodies, though fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) and hematoxylin-eosin method can also be used. Quinacrine Dihydrochloride is used to stain Y chromosome.

choices.text: i, iii & iv are right; ii is wrong
i & iii are right; ii & iv are wrong
ii & iv are right; i & iii are wrong

questions.text:
i - Swallow tail may be seen in stab wounds
ii - Stretch lacerations are caused by horizontal force
iii - Fish tailing may be seen in incised wounds
iv - Bleeding is usually more in lacerated wounds than incised wounds
questions.solution:
• Tearing at the ends, at angles diverging from the main one in a lacerated wound is known as swallow tail.
  • Stretch lacerations are caused by tangential force. Normally single edged knife causes a wedge-shaped wound; but sometimes the blunt end of the blade may tear the skin in the form of the shape of a tail of a fish, known as fish tailing.
  • Bleeding is usually less in lacerated wounds than incised wounds due to crushing of the vessels.

questions.text: Match the personalities with their invention/discovery
questions.solution:
• Tearing at the ends, at angles diverging from the main one in a lacerated wound is known as swallow tail.
  • Stretch lacerations are caused by tangential force. Normally single edged knife causes a wedge-shaped wound; but sometimes the blunt end of the blade may tear the skin in the form of the shape of a tail of a fish, known as fish tailing.
  • Bleeding is usually less in lacerated wounds than incised wounds due to crushing of the vessels.

choices.text: Growth at the site following trauma
Age related changes in the teeth

questions.text: Ewing's postulates concerns with which of the following:
questions.solution:
• Ewing's postulates should be satisfied before a relationship between Trauma and New growth (Trauma and Tumor) is accepted.
  1. Evidence of previous integrity of the injured part.
  2. Undeniable and Adequate trauma must be proved.
  3. There must be a proof of reasonable time interval between injury and appearance of tumor.
  4. Disease must develop at the exact site of Injury.
  5. The nature of the tumor must be proved.

questions.text: Medical qualifications awarded by institutions outside India and recognized by NMC are registered in
questions.solution:
• The NMC recognized Medical Qualifications are mentioned under 3 schedules:
  • The First Schedule: Contains the recognized medical qualification granted by Universities in India.
  • The Second schedule: Contains the recognized medical qualifications granted outside India.
  • Third schedule has two parts:
    • Part I: Contains medical qualifications granted by Indian Universities which are not included in First schedule
    • Part II: Contains medical qualifications granted by Foreign Universities which are not included in Second schedule

questions.text:
True about bomb blast:
A. Injuries may be due to burns or air blast
B. Force of explosion is mostlly directional
C. Force of explosion decreases rapidly
D. Bruise, laceration and abrasions are triad of main injuries seen
questions.solution: • In case of bomb blast the force of explosion decreases rapidly. The injuries may be due to burns or air blast (Shock waves and blast wind). Bruises, lacerations and abrasions are the main injuries (Marshal's triad) seen in case of bomb blast. The force of explosion is concentrical and not directional.

questions.text: The causative electrode of electric injury can be identified by
questions.solution:
• Acro-reaction test is a microchemical test to detect the metal on the skin derived from the causative electrode.
  • Small balls of molten metal, derived from the electrode, may be carried deep into the tissues known as current pearls.
  • Heat generated by the current may melt the calcium phosphate, which is seen radiologically as typical round density foci, known as, Bone pearls or Wax drippings.

questions.text: 'Hot shot' is
questions.solution:
• Hot Shot -> Heroin + Strychnine
  • Crack (smokable form) -> Cocaine + Baking soda
  • Mickey Finn -> Alcohol + Chloral hydrate
  • Speed ball means combination of a Depressant and a Stimulant -> Heroin + Cocaine

questions.text: Fragmented medulla of hair may be seen in
questions.solution: • Not all hairs have medullae, and when they do exist, it may be continuous, interrupted or fragmented. Human hair, except for the hair of native Mongolians, has either no medulla or a fragmented medulla. Mongoloids usually have continuous medulla.

choices.text: Breadth of first sacral vertebra x 100/breadth of fifth lumbar vertebra
Breadth of fifth lumbar vertebra x 100/breadth of all sacral vertebra
Breadth of first sacral vertebra x 100/breadth of base of sacrum
Breadth of fifth lumbar vertebra x 100/breadth of base of sacrum

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding corporobasal index of sacrum?
questions.solution: Corporo-basal index is used to differentiate the sex by sacrum.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female has come to the emergency room with acids burns on the face. History revealed the injuries were caused by Mr. 'X', as she refused to befriend with him. Mr. 'X' is punishable under which Section of I.P.C.?
questions.solution:
• Section 320 of IPC defines grievous hurt.
  • Section 326A deals with voluntarily causing grievous hurt by use of acid (Minimum 10 years of imprisonment which may extend to life + Fine).
  • Section 326B deals with voluntarily throwing or attempting to throw acid (Minimum 5 years of imprisonment which may extend to 7 years + Fine)

questions.text: One of the following is not a cardiac poison
questions.solution:
The cardiac poisons are: Nicotiana tabacum, Digitalis purpurea (Picture No. ii), Nerium odorum/white oleander/pink oleander (Picture No. iv), Cerbera Thevetia (Yellow oleander, Cerbera odallam (Suicide tree), Aconite/Sweet Poison/Meetha Zehar/Monk's hood/ Devil's helmet (Picture No. iii) and Quinine.

Picture No. i is of Conium (Hemlock), which is a peripheral nerve poison.

questions.text: Forensic entomology may help in determining
questions.solution: • The time since death can be estimated by the different stages of life cycle of insects. By identifying the specific insects in the specific area one can determine the place of death. The poison can be isolated from the maggots in case of death due to poisoning as the larvae eat up the tissue.

questions.text: Dead body of a 30 years old married woman was recovered from a burning hut. The body was charred with pugilistic attitude. There was surface fracture of the cranium with chocolate brown heat haematoma. The findings are suggestive of -
questions.solution:
The definite signs of antemortem burns are:

  1. Presence of soot in the trachea/bronchial tree
  2. Blisters containing albumin, chloride, RBCs & WBCs with a red line at the periphery
  3. More than 10% carboxyHb in the blood.

The pugilistic attitude, surface fractures of the cranium and heat hematoma are not signs of antemortem burns.

questions.text: Match the given diagnostics tests for poisoning
questions.solution:
• Marquis Test, Denige's Test and Husemann's Test are used to identify Opium.
  • Kunkel's Test '(Tannic Acid Test), Wetzel's Test and Hoppe-Seyler's Test are used to identify Carbon monoxide.
  • Cavette's Tet , Hine & Kozelka Test and Dichromate Test are used to detect ethanol.
  • Lee Jones test is used to detect Cyanide and salicylates.

questions.text: Identify
questions.solution: • Dum dum bullet is a jacketed bullet with nose cut off. Express bullet or hollow point is a bullet with a hole in the tip. In case of explosive bullet, the bullet tip is grilled and tiny canister containing Lead azide is inserted and on impact, the bullet explodes.

questions.text: Nitro guanidine is used as a propellant charge in
questions.solution: • Smokeless powder may be Single based which contain only Nitrocellulose or Double based which contain Nitrocellulose + Nitroglycerine or Triple based which contain Nitrocellulose + Nitroglycerine + Nitroguanidine.

questions.text: Cause of death in Commotio cordis is
questions.solution: • Commotio cordis typically involves young (8-18 years; average age is 15), predominantly male athletes in whom a sudden, blunt, non-penetrating and innocuous-appearing trauma to the anterior chest results in cardiac arrest and sudden death from ventricular fibrillation.

questions.text: The stature from fragmentary bones can be estimated by
questions.solution:
Stature from long bones can be estimated by measuring the length of long bones and by using regression formulae, such as, Jit and Sing formula, Trotter and Glesser's formula, Karl-Pearson's formula and Duperius & Hadden's formula.

Steele and McKern's Formula is used to estimate the stature from fragmentary bones.

Smith and Fidde's Formula is used to estimate the stature from fetal bones.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution: Self explanatory

questions.text: Yellow Poppy gives rise to
questions.solution:
• The plant of Argemone Mexicana is known as Yellow Poppy. The oil contains two alkaloids, sanguinarine and dihydrosanguinarine which causes epidemic dropsy.
  • Spastic paraplegia/quadriplegia is caused by consumption of Kesari dhal (Lathyrus sativus).
  • Flashback Phenomenon and Bad trip are commonly seen in LSD addiction.

questions.text: Reversal of hot/cold temperature perception is seen in
questions.solution:
• Ciguatera poisoning is caused by eating reef fish, which produces ciguatoxin which alters the Na+ permeability giving rise to reversal of hot/cold temperature perception, i.e., hot substances feel cold and cold substances feel hot.
  • Gymnothorax poisoning is caused by eating Moray eels, giving rise to prominent abdominal breathing & absent thoracic breathing.
  • Scombroid food poisoning is caused by eating spoiled fish. The histidine is converted into histamine giving rise to allergic reaction
  • The coumarin present in the sweet clover is converted into Vit. K antagonist dicoumarol, giving rise to haemorrhagic disease.

questions.text: One of the following is a spinal inhibitory poison
questions.solution: Conium (aka Hemlock) and Curare are peripheral nerve poisons. Gelsemium is a spinal inhibitory poison.

choices.text: The ratio of the weight of lung to the weight of the body is 1:70
Dome of the diaphragm is at the level of 4th or 5th rib

questions.text: One of the following statements is WRONG with regard to un-respired lungs
questions.solution:
• The alveoli in un-respired lung will be lined by columnar epithelium whereas in respired lung it will be lined by squamous epithelium.
  • The weight of un-respired lung is about 35gand of respired lung is about 70g.
  • The ratio of the weight of un-respired lung to the weight of the body is 1:70 and that of respired lung is 1:35.
  • Dome of the diaphragm is at the level of 4th or 5th rib in case of un-respired lung and at the level of 6th or 7th rib in case of respired lung.

questions.text: One of the following test is not used for detection of semen
questions.solution:
• Aminophthalhydrazide is the reagent used in Luminol test - Invisible blood stains can be identified even in case of washed blood Most sensitive presumptive test for blood)
  • Microscopic examination, detection of sperm specific LDH isoenzyme, UV light, Seminal Acid phosphatase (SAP) test, Barberio's test, Florence test, PSA (Prostate Specific Antigen)/p30, TLC, CPK and Zinc test are used to detect seminal stain.

questions.text: Disrobe is punishable under IPC section
questions.solution:
• Sec.354 IPC - Assault or criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty (Indecent assault)
  • Sec.354a IPC – Sexual harassment
  • Sec.354b IPC - Disrobe
  • Sec.354c IPC - Voyeurism
  • Sec.354c IPC - Stalking

questions.text: Phadebas test is used to detect
questions.solution:
• Phadebas test, Starch-Iodine test or α-amylase test and Fluorescence spectroscopy are used to detect Saliva and can be confirmed by the presence of buccal squamous cells.
  • Milk can be identified by the presence of caseine & lactose.
  • Colostrum can be identified by the presence of trypsin inhibitor.
  • Urine can be identified by the presence of urea & Creatinine.

choices.text: To know the mode of drowning
To know the urinary excretion of toxins

questions.text: Pyrogallol test is performed for which of the following?
questions.solution: • Alkaline Pyragolol test is used to differentiate air embolism from putrefactive gases. 4 mL of alkaline pyrogallol is taken in a 10ml syringe and air is aspirated from right side of the heart. The needle is removed and replaced by a stopper. If air (Oxygen) is present, the mixture turns brown on shaking. In case of putrefactive gases, the colour does not change.

questions.text:
Seen in hydrofluoric acid poisoning
A. Decreased Mg+2
B. Decreased K+
C. Decreased Ca+2
D. Increased H+
E. Increased Na2
questions.solution:
• Hydrofluoric acid poisoning cause Severe throbbing pain, Tissue destruction and necrosis,
  • Acidosis, Hypocalcemia, Hypomagnesemia and Hyperkalemia.

questions.text: Bhilawanol is an active ingredient of?
questions.solution:
• Semecarpol and Bhilawanol are active ingredients of Semecarpus Anacardium (Marking nut).
  • Hyoscine, Hyoscyamine & traces of atropine are active ingredients of datura.
  • Abrin, Abrine, Abralin & Abric Acid are active ingredients of Abrus Precatorius.
  • Ricin is the active Ingredient of Ricinus communis.

questions.text: In case of bodies recovered from water, hypostasis is seen in all the parts EXCEPT
questions.solution: • In case of bodies lying in water, the post-mortem staining is usually found on the face, the upper part of the chest, hands, lower arms, feet and legs, as the body usually floats face down, buttocks up with limbs hanging down in front of the body.

questions.text: Prominent early signs of cyanide poisoning include all EXCEPT
questions.solution: • Cyanide poisoning manifests with convulsions, dilated pupils, initially bradycardia and hypertension followed by tachycardia and hypotension, tachypnea followed by bradypnea, pulmonary edema and brick red colour of skin and mucus membrane. Cyanosis is a late feature.

choices.text: At the will of the person
Person incapable of making their will
Against the will of the person
Against the will of the parents

questions.text: 'Non voluntary Euthanasia' means
questions.solution:
• Active Euthanasia: Inflicting painless death by an act of commission e.g. injecting large doses of barbiturates/KCl/curare etc.
  • Passive Euthanasia: Inflicting painless death by an act of omission e.g. withdrawal of life saving measures/life support.
  • Voluntary Euthanasia: With the consent of the dying person.
  • Involuntary (Compulsory) Euthanasia: Without/against the consent of the person.
  • Non voluntary Euthanasia: The person is incapable of making their wishes known, e.g., In cases of irreversibly comatose patient, severely defective patients etc.

questions.text: Domain of ballistics concerned with forensic pathologist is
questions.solution:
• Forensic ballistics: It is the science dealing with the investigation of firearms, ammunition and the problems arising from their use.
  • Proximal/Interior/Internal Ballistics: Physiochemical phenomenon from the time of detonation till the projectile leaves the barrel.
  • Exterior/External Ballistics: Study of the projective from the time it leaves the barrel till it reaches the target.
  • Terminal/Wound Ballistics: Study of effect of the projectile on the target (Study of wound).
  • The domain of ballistics concerned with forensic pathologist is Wound ballistics.

questions.text: The father of Modern Forensic Medicine is
questions.solution:
• Paolo Zacchia (1584-1659) is the father of Forensic Medicine.
  • Bernard Spilsbury (1877-1947) is the father of Modern Forensic Medicine.
  • Mathieu Orfila (1787-1853) is the father of Modern Toxicology.
  • Paracelsus (1493-1541) is the father of Toxicology

choices.text: Use reasonable amount of force and examine
Ask the Investigating officer to get a court order

questions.text: An arrested person who is accused of rape is brought to you at CHC for examination who is not willing to consent for the same. What should be done in this case?
questions.solution:
Sec. 53 CrPC: Examination of accused by medical practitioner at the request of police officer.

(1) When a person is arrested on a charge of committing an offence of such a nature and alleged to have been committed under such circumstances that there are reasonable grounds for believing that an examination of his person will afford evidence as to the commission of an offence, it shall be lawful for a registered medical practitioner, acting at the request of a police officer not below the rank of sub-inspector, and for any person acting in good faith in his aid and under his direction, to make such an examination of the person arrested as is reasonably necessary in order to ascertain the facts which may afford such evidence, and to use such force as is reasonably for that purpose.

(2) Whenever the person of a female is to be examined under this section, the examination shall be made only by, or under the supervision of, a female registered medical practitioner.

questions.text: The method of age estimation by height and weight of teeth is
questions.solution:
• Mile's method: This is used by studying only the root transparency of a tooth after the age of 30 years.
  • Boyde's method: Cross striations in the enamel and dentine of deciduous teeth and permanent first molars represent daily incremental lines. Studied by histological sections. The age of an individual can be calculated by counting the number of lines from neonatal line onwards. Neonatal line is considered as an indicator of birth. This method is applicable mainly to infants. The age so calculated is accurate with an error of around 20 days.
  • Stack's method: Estimation of the age of infants from the weight and height of the erupting teeth of child. It is used on both deciduous and permanent during their erupting phase.
  • Lamendil's method: Estimation of age from using only 2 criteria namely, gingival recession and root transparency.

questions.text: When an autopsy surgeon wants to send the maggots for examination, it should be preserved in
questions.solution:
• Supersaturated sodium chloride or rectified spirit is used as a preservative for body viscera.
  • Acetic alcohol is used as preservative for maggots. Maggots are killed by dropping into boiling absolute alcohol (so that it dies in extended position) and preserved in Acetic alcohol.
  • Dimethyl sulphoxide (DMSO) is used as a preservative for muscle for DNA.

questions.text: One of the following is the first enzyme/biochemical markers to be released at the site of wound
questions.solution:
Sequence of enzymes/biochemical markers rising after injury:

  • Tissue cathepsin (5-10 min)
  • Serotonin (10 min)
  • Histamines (20-30 min)
  • Esterase and ATPase (within 1 hour)
  • Aminopeptidase (2 hours)
  • Acidphosphatase (4 hours)
  • Alkaline phosphatase (6 hours)

questions.text:
True statement(s) about exhumation:
A. Police can order for exhumation
B. Executive magistrate can order for exhumation
C. Post-mortem cannot be done on exhumated body
D. CrPC 176(4) is related to enquiry of exhumated body
E. CrPC 174 is related to enquiry of exhumated body
questions.solution: • Exhumation requires an order from Executive magistrate, as per Sec. 176(4) of Cr.P.C.

questions.text:
True regarding post-mortem changes:
A. Fixation of cadaveric lividity occur in around 8 hr (range 6-12 hr)
B. Rigor mortis occur when ATP decreased to 85% of normal level
C. Cherry red colour hypostasis occur due to CO poisoning
D. Rigor mortis delay & persists longer in cholera & typhoid
E. Livor mortis usually occur on dependent part
questions.solution:
• Fixation of cadaveric lividity occur in around 8 hours and at an average of 6-12 hours.
  • Rigor mortis starts when ATP level decreased to 85% of normal level.
  • Cherry red colour hypostasis is seen in CO poisoning.
  • Rigor mortis starts early and passes off early in infectious diseases like gas gangrene, cholera, typhoid, TB etc. (but not in pneumonia) and it is frequently absent in septicemia.
  • Livor mortis occurs on dependent parts of the body.

choices.text: Seen on opposite side of area of impact
Most common site is frontal & temporal lobes
Fall on temporal area may produce contrecoup injury on ipsilateral lobe
Fall on frontal area produce contrecoup injury on occipital lobe

questions.text: False statement in contre coup injuries is
questions.solution:
Coup injury is the injury which is seen at the site of impact and contrecoup injury is the injury seen on opposite side of area of impact.

Contrecoup injury is more common in frontal and temporal lobes.

Fall on temporal area may produce contrecoup injury on ipsilateral lobe due to impact with the falx cerebri

Contrecoup injury is almost nil in occipital lobe

choices.text: A nurse employed by hospital assists in operation by a surgeon who is also hospital's employee
A surgeon employed in one hospital provides his services in other hospital
A nurse employed by hospital assists in operation by a surgeon who is not that hospital's employee

questions.text: Doctrine of borrowed servant is applicable on
questions.solution: As per borrowed servant doctrine, when an employee is borrowed from the principle employer by a new temporary employer, the temporary new employer will be held liable for the negligent act of the employee and not the principle employer.

questions.text:
A dumb witness
A. Is not allowed to testify in a court of law
B. Can testify by signs in an open court
C. By producing a previously written statement
D. By writing in an open court
E. Can testify by head signs to leading questions
questions.solution: A dumb witness can testify in court of law by  any form of signs by hands or head or by writing in an open court.

questions.text:
Indices used to determine sex of an individual are
A. Intermembral
B. Corporobasal
C. Sternal
D. Ischiopubic
E. Crural
questions.solution:
Indices to differentiate race are:

  1. Brachial index (Radio-humeral index)
  2. Crural index (Tibio-femoral index)
  3. Intra-membral index (Humero-femoral index)
  4. Inter-membral index
  5. Cephalic Index

Indices to differentiate sex from bones are

  1. Sternal index
  2. Ischio-pubic index (WASHBURN INDEX)
  3. Sciatic notch index
  4. Sacral Index:
  5. Corporo-basal index (Only index, which is more in Males)
  6. Medullary Index (Also to differentiate human hair from animal hair)
